Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Quantifying Nitrogen Limitation in the Gut Microbiota
Award.AbstractNarration:
The availability of different types of nutrients can determine which species are able live together. When microbes (such as bacteria) live inside animals (such as humans), they may compete for a limited nutrient (such as nitrogen) or may cooperate with each other to acquire that same nutrient. This project will examine how humans and the bacteria in their guts manage their needs for nitrogen. Humans get nitrogen from their diet, and gut bacteria get nitrogen from inside their human hosts. The bacteria can either compete with humans for nitrogen in swallowed food or they can be "fed" through material that humans excrete into the gut. The researchers will focus on competition for nitrogen in the gut and test whether it is important in determining which species of bacteria can live there. The results of this work may help in the design of treatments that require a change in the community of bacteria living in the guts of sick people and domestic animals.

The hypothesis that nitrogen is limiting in the gut comes from the observation that most indigestible material reaching the large intestine is nitrogen poor and, therefore, there is little nitrogen available to most of the gut's microbiota. This leads to two testable predictions. First, there is a longitudinal gradient in the environmental (non-microbial) carbon-to-nitrogen (C:N) ratio and a depletion of diet-sourced nitrogen along a healthy gut. Second, much of the nitrogen used by bacteria must come from host secretions. These predictions will be tested by measuring C:N ratios along the gut and by using stable isotope tracer studies to identify the fate of dietary nitrogen and the source of bacterial nitrogen. Finally, to determine if changes in nitrogen availability can alter microbial community composition in the gut, in vitro co-culture competition experiments will be conducted under varying levels of nitrogen availability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitrogen is an element crucial for all life and is often a limiting nutrient for growth. This work focused on understanding how nitrogen was shared between mammals and their gut microbes. We hypothesized that nitrogen would be limiting for the microbiota because the animal has first access to nitrogen in the diet. Such limitation would then affect microbial growth and community composition.
Indeed, we found that nitrogen is relatively rare in the large intestine and that adding more nitrogen increased the number of microbes in the gut. By tracing the fate of added nitrogen, we showed that microbes get much of their nitrogen from proteins the host secretes into the gut rather than from diet. Furthermore, we found that a particular group of bacteria, members of the Bacteroidetes, are the primary foragers of nitrogen regardless of its source. By providing secretions or allowing more dietary nitrogen to reach the gut, the animal host can promote the growth of these microbes, which are known from other work to provide many benefits to the animal.
Therefore, we believe that the host can use nitrogen availability to manipulate the composition of the gut microbial community and that this may serve as a platform for medical manipulations as well. Notably, this control would come at a cost to the host in particular allocating nitrogen to the microbes would limit the hosts own growth.We showed that under antibiotics, mice secrete less nitrogen into the gut and so we propose that the additional growth observed under antibiotic treatment comes from this reallocation of nitrogen to the animal from the microbes.
In addition to these novel findings, this grant funded work that was included in a PhD dissertation and provided opportunities for training undergraduates. Many trainees who worked on this project are from historically underrepresented groups in the sciences. In addition, the graduate student associated with the project presented this work to scientific and public audiences and is preparing a classroom lesson based around microbial science that she has workshopped with multiple elementary classes in the Durham NC public school system.
